block.p: Re "Logging in Siberia Sets Off a Battle in the U.S." (news article, Jan. 30), on our joint Russian-American project to sterilize Russian logs with radiation to make them safe for export to the United States:

Re "Logging in Siberia Sets Off a Battle in the U.S." (news article, Jan. 30), on our joint Russian-American project to sterilize Russian logs with radiation to make them safe for export to the United States:

The project will be carried out with tree replanting beyond the strict United States Forest Service guidelines required of projects benefiting from United States Government financing, potentially increasing tree storage of carbon dioxide.

Sterilizing logs with gamma rays solves the problem of a commercially feasible, environmentally friendly technology for substitution of the pesticide methyl bromide, which has been used in logs entering world trade.
Without this technology, pressure from agriculture and forestry interests will result in a delay in the phaseout of methyl bromide, a contributor to ozone depletion and global warming.
RONALD F. MULLER ALEXANDER RIMSKI -KORSAKOV Arlington, Va., Feb. 2, 1996
The writers are, respectively, chief executive officer and manager for technology and operations, Russian American Ionized Energy Services.
